awd_titl_txt: Shape Deviation Generator and Learner - An Engineering-Informed Convolution Modeling and Learning Framework for Additive Manufacturing Accuracy Control
awd_abstract_narration:
Although additive manufacturing (AM), known as 3D Printing, holds great promise as a direct manufacturing technology, significant deviations from the desired part shape often occur in the printed parts.  As a result,shape distortion control is a critical issue for AM built products. With advances in computing and increased accessibility of AM product data, machine learning for AM has become a viable strategy for enhancing 3D printing performance. However, meaningful learning of engineering data requires effective integration of domain knowledge, making general-purpose machine learning methods difficult to apply. As a result, there is a critical need for an engineering-informed, data-analytical, machine learning framework for shape distortion control.  Such a tool is essential to improving AM quality and reducing cost and waste. 

The project will establish an engineering-informed convolution modeling and learning methodological framework for AM distortion control. A Shape Deviation Generator and Learner for shape accuracy control will be researched by: (1) modeling 3D shape deviation generation by establishing a new convolution formulation for layer-by-layer fabrication processes, (2) transferring the 3D shape deviation model from a small set of training shapes to a wider variety of shapes by exploring and learning shape similarity under a cookie-cutter modeling framework, (3) transferring the shape deviation model between AM processes by exploring and learning process similarity through an effect equivalence framework, and (4) validating modeling and transfer learning methodologies in both polymer and metal AM processes. Methodologies and tools will be developed to mitigate both shape and process complexities towards the goal of building AM products with high geometric fidelity: from single shape to multiple shapes, and from single process to multiple AM processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to control geometric shape quality for one-of-a-kind additive manufacturing. Existing statistical quality control methods are hardly applicable because of the complexity due to the large product variety and layer-wise fabrication. Applying machine learning approaches not only requires large amounts of costly data but also falls short of gaining engineering insights for process improvement and knowledge generalization. 

To address the quality control challenges in one-of-a-kind additive manufacturing, this research project established the Shape Deviation Generator and Learner (SDG&L) as a set of engineering-informed convolution learning approaches for small-sample learning and prediction of 3D shape quality. First and foremost, the SDG&L modeled the layer-by-layer additive manufacturing process using a mathematical convolution formulation. This process-informed formulation not only connected the 2D printing of layers with 3D printing/generation of shapes but also significantly reduced the requirement of large data for model training. Furthermore, the SDG&L explored and learned 3D shape similarity under a new cookie-cutter modeling framework to enable the transfer learning of a small set of training 3D shapes to a wider variety of new shapes. Compared to the computation-intensive physics-based simulation and data-intensive machine learning methods, SDG&L achieved cost effectiveness by integrating process knowledge into a new data analytical learning framework. Experimental validation showed the effectiveness of SDG&L methodologies in both polymer-based and metal-based additive manufacturing processes. The research outcomes contribute to establishing the foundation of engineering-informed machine learning for additive manufacturing and quality control methodologies for one-of-a-kind manufacturing. 

To ensure data quality, this project also developed shape registration methods for product quality assessment. The most adopted Iterative Closest Point (ICP) algorithm faces several potential pitfalls in additive manufacturing (AM). A more robust alignment procedure was developed for AM-specific applications. Furthermore, to reduce the dependence on human interventions such as the manual selection of landmarks or features for registration, an automated landmark selection method was developed for complicated geometries such as teeth. A method of segmenting point cloud data into layers was developed to qualify products built by wire arc additive manufacturing processes. 

The developed methodologies have been reported in top journals and conferences in the field. The publications won the 2021 IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering Best Conference Paper Award, the honorable mention of the 2021 NAMRC Student Research Presentation Award, and the finalist of the Student Manufacturing Design Competition in the 2021 NAMRC & MSEC Manufacturing Research Conference. One patent application and one invention disclosure have been filed. A new course ?System Monitoring and Causal Inference with Complex Engineering Data? was developed and offered in 2021 and a new book is forthcoming in 2024. Two Ph.D. students working on the proposed research have graduated, and one more is expected to graduate in 2024. Six undergraduate students have been involved in machine learning for 3D printing research, among which three are from the under-represented group. Two of them were supported through the REU supplement. The research outcomes are disseminated through invited visits and talks nationally and internationally, including a keynote speech in Mexico. An international workshop on the Foundation of Accuracy Control for Additive Manufacturing was organized at the University of Southern California in 2020 with participants from the US, France, Italy, and Canada.Industrial collaborations and technology transfer have been undertaken with two 3D printing companies on product qualification and process monitoring.

 


Last Modified: 09/26/2023
Modified by: Qiang Huang
